SCHOOLS BUILT SINCE 1959
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Education (a) how many schools have been built since 1959; (b) are all those schools provided with adequate sports grounds; and (c) in how many of those schools have the ground floors cracked; what are the reasons for the cracks; and has any remedial action been taken.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1959 the Government has built 55 primary and 56 secondary schools, and one junior college. All Government schools are provided with playgrounds, but the size of these playgrounds varies, depending on the availability of land. In the past years it has become increasingly difficult to secure school sites in or near to the heart of the city big enough to provide adequate playing fields. Where

Column: 960

such grounds are not quite adequate, the schools concerned are encouraged to share other school playing fields in the neighbourhood or to use public open spaces and sporting amenities belonging to community centres. On the whole, the provision of grounds for sports and games in schools is quite adequate.

    Over the past three or four years, several cracks have developed in some parts of the ground floors of five schools as a result of the sinking floors. However, these occurred only in schools built on low-lying sites that had been filled. Remedial action has been taken by the Public Works Department to reinforce the concrete ground floors in these five schools.

Column: 960

RURAL AREAS
(Applications for free water supply)


    2. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) what are the procedures in

Column: 961

respect of an application for free water supply to rural areas, where water-mains are not available, during a drought; and (b) how long it will take for such an application to be considered.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, all requests for the supply of drinking water can be made orally or in writing to the Chairman, Secretary, or District Secretaries of the Urban and Rural Services Committee. Such requests are attended to immediately, and water is supplied as soon as the number of households requiring water is ascertained.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House which department is responsible for ascertaining the number of households?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Water Department of the Public Utilities Board has been requested to ascertain the number of households.

Column: 961

OVERSEAS MARKETS FOR
POULTRY PRODUCTS


    3. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Law and National Development what efforts have been made by the Primary Production Department in the promotion of overseas markets for poultry products.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Primary Production Department is essentially a technical department whose efforts are directed towards assisting farmers to produce better livestock and better crops. Export promotion is not one of its functions. However, the Department is in constant touch with the Economic Development Board, Intraco, and exporting firms to encourage export of our livestock products.

Column: 962



    The most important prerequisite of export promotion is, of course, to maintain a high standard of our products. Towards this end, the Primary Production Department insists on certain veterinary health standards to ensure that poultry and other livestock products are wholesome and that processing and canning factories comply with certain hygienic standards. As a result, our poultry products are allowed entry into and exported to several countries, like Australia, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong, and Vietnam.

2.38 p.m.

    Head 0902 -

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0902 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs. P. Govindaswamy, N. Govindasamy, Cheong Yuen Chee, Lim Soo Peng, J. F. Conceicao, P. Selvadurai, and Madam Chan Choy Siong.)

    Sir, can the Minister inform the House how many foreigners who have invested $125,000 or $250,000 here have been given permanent residence in the Republic? Does he not think that these investments are too small a sum for foreigners to be given permanent residence in Singapore? There are also people who have invested millions of dollars either in industries or hotels. These people are not permanent residents but are living in Singapore on visas granted to them on a yearly basis by the Immigration Department. If they apply for permanent residence, will their applications be approved on the strength of their investments?

    As regards the entry of non-citizen wives into Singapore, the Minister answered an oral question on this topic asked by the Member for Geylang Serai on 9th March, 1970. My question is this: will the Minister consider asking the Immigration Department to maintain close liaison with the Registry of Marriages? In this respect, perhaps a questionnaire can be given to those citizens who wish to marry non-citizen wives to complete and return either to the Registry of Marriages or the Immigration Department. If this measure is introduced, it will caution Singapore citizens of the consequences of taking

Column: 964

non-citizen wives. They will then be more careful about marrying non-citizens. However, this measure perhaps deserves consideration, especially when our male population exceeds our female population by about 85,000, according to a recent census taken in the Republic.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that many Singapore citizens in the lower income group who have wives outside Singapore are not allowed to bring them here to stay, even if they are qualified to do so. May I know the reasons for refusal?

    The other point is the case of a boy who was born in China but who came to Singapore in 1956. Some time later, he went to work in Kuala Lumpur. His parents, brothers and sisters are all Singapore citizens and are staying here, and he used to travel up and down Malaysia. One day, while coming down to Singapore to visit his family, he was caught unawares by the travel restrictions imposed at the Causeway, and his blue Singapore identity card was taken away by the Immigration authorities at the Woodlands checkpoint, as he did not follow the proper procedure. He was sent back to Malaysia. Unfortunately, his Malaysian work permit had also expired and could not be renewed. As a result, this boy, who is only 17 years old, is jobless and is stranded in Kuala Lumpur. He has no relatives there, and is left to face starvation. He then cabled his father in Singapore saying that he wanted to join his family. The father applied to the Immigration authorities for consideration of his son's case, but the application was rejected. The boy's family are all Singapore citizens, and there is a job here waiting for him. Will the Minister consider returning the blue Singapore identity card to him so that he can stay with his family in Singapore?

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, from the list of Members who have given notice to

Column: 965

speak on this subhead, it is clear that the Immigration Department is in for a lot of criticism. However, I will confine myself to just one aspect, and that is, locally-domiciled residents who are non-citizens. When these people wish to travel abroad, they are issued with certificates of identity, and only on urgent grounds. Generally they are allowed to travel only from Singapore to Malaysia, and their certificates of identity are good for one journey only. Sir, most of these people travel for the purpose of visiting sick relatives or urgent private matters; in certain cases they travel for some festive occasion.

2.45 p.m.

    Sir, the Immigration Department charges something like $24.60 for this certificate of identity, which includes reentry permit charges, etc. In my opinion, $24.60 is a little too much, especially when only one trip can be made, and in some cases this trip is made only as far as Johore Bahru. Sir, for a Singapore resident to visit a sick relative in Johore Bahru, and to have to pay a fee of $24.60 is, in my opinion, too much when you consider the fact that an international passport, which has a life span of five years, costs only $25 and can be used for as many trips as one likes. On the one hand, we charge $24.60 for a certificate of identity for one trip to East Malaysia. On the other hand, we are generous enough to maintain the archaic practice of paying good conduct allowances to our policemen.

    The issue of these certificates of identity is also a little too restrictive. When one applies for a certificate of identity to visit a sick relative in Malaysia, one has to show proof of illness in the form of either a telegram or a letter, etc. Our telephone system is efficient, and more often than not, the news of the illness of a relative across the Causeway is often made via the telephone. Therefore, requiring proof of illness in the form of a letter or a telegram is, I think, making it a little too difficult and inconveniencing the local residents. Therefore, I would suggest that more liberal consideration be given to this

Column: 966

issue of certificates of identity by the Immigration Department. At the same time, I would be grateful to the Minister if he would look into the possibility of reducing the cost for a certificate of identity.

    Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the past many of our citizens have gone across the Causeway to seek employment. The recent action by the Malaysian Government to restrict employment opportunities to our citizens has forced many of them to return to Singapore to earn a living.

    During their period of residence in Malaysia, many of these citizens have raised families there. For obvious reasons, the members of their families have taken out Malaysian identity cards. The men-folk, however, were allowed entry into Singapore without any restriction, but not the wives and children of these citizens.

    I have raised this problem with the Immigration Department, and was surprised to receive a reply stating that the people concerned could only apply for social visit passes for the members of their family in this instance, as there is no provision in the regulations to enable them to return to Singapore for permanent residence. Will the Minister consider measures to assist the families of these Singapore citizens who are affected by the Malaysian Government's action to return and reside permanently in Singapore?

    Mr Lim Soo Peng (Havelock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am informed that there are quite a few cases of people who were denied entry into Singapore because their passports had expired. These people, all Singapore citizens, were in Indonesia or somewhere else, and, for one reason or other, could not renew their passports. Later on, when they wanted to renew their passports, they were not allowed to do so. Without renewing their passports, they were not allowed reentry into Singapore. Will the Minister state whether it is his policy to deny such people readmission into Singapore? If so, please state the rationale behind it.

Column: 967



    Mr J. F. Conceicao: I am not moving my amendment, Sir.

    Mr P. Selvadurai (Bukit Panjang): I am also not moving my amendment, Sir.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin):Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to touch on a certain case concerning the immigration regulations and, at the same time, to air my complaints. With the achievement of independence, it is our duty to create employment opportunities for our own citizens. Therefore, it is necessary for the Immigration Department to take measures against illegal immigrants entering our country to share in our prosperity. I think everyone agrees with this policy. However, I think the Immigration Department should relax some of its regulations. For example, one regulation is that if a person wishes to apply for his relative to come to Singapore, he has to state the age of his relative and their relationship before he or she can be admitted into Singapore. If a son wants to apply for his mother to come to Singapore, he must first prove that she is more than 65 years old and that she has no other people abroad to support her. If a husband wants to apply for his wife to come to Singapore, there are certain regulations which state that she can be allowed into Singapore to be reunited with him provided they have met each other within a certain period. All these regulations are laid down by the Government and everybody must abide by them. Although sometimes I feel that all these regulations must be observed, I still think we should relax them.

    I have one example of a husband who applied for his wife, who is in China, to come to Singapore to be reunited with him. However, according to the Immigration Department, if the husband has not met his wife for five years, it means that the husband and wife relationship has been broken off. It so happened that when this person applied for his wife to come to Singapore, she fell sick. As a result, she was not able to come here. So he was not successful

Column: 968

in his application. He wanted to visit her in China but was not able to do so. Five years later - his wife had by then recovered from her sickness - he reapplied for her to come to Singapore. However, the Immigration Department rejected it on the grounds that she was not eligible for entry into Singapore because he had not met her for five years, and, according to the regulations, she could not come here. This person came to me for help, and I informed the Minister concerned about it. But he said, since there were so many women in Singapore, why did he not want to marry a local female citizen? I told him that this man was already past 60 years of age, so how could he marry another young girl locally? I also told him that, according to Chinese custom, a man is not allowed to take another wife if the present wife still lives. This man also said that he had married his wife out of love. It was not an arranged marriage. Their love for each other was very deep and they were willing to live together to the end of their lives. Therefore, how could we force them to separate? This person was in despair and he asked his son to apply for his mother to come to Singapore. As she was then 67 years of age, the Immigration Department said that at this age she was eligible to come to Singapore. However, when the son applied for an entry permit for his mother, it was not granted because another application had already been made on her behalf by his father. I then asked the son to try again. However, when he was about to send in his application to the Immigration Department, the father died.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are all human and laws are made by man. Therefore, all these troubles created by man should be resolved by man.

    Arising from this case, we should be sympathetic to certain applicants in future. In this particular case, we should have tried our best to help him reunite with his wife before he died. That was his wish. But under the circumstances this was not fulfilled because he could not see her. This is an example of our Government not being in sympathy with

Column: 969

the applicant. Everything must be done according to the law, it is said. I hope the Minister will be sympathetic to applications of this nature in future.

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will reply first to the Member for Changi before proceeding to the other Members who have raised almost the same points. The Member for Changi wants to know how many foreigners who have invested between $125,000 and $250,000 have been given permanent residence in Singapore. I regret to say that I do not carry the figures around in my head. But if the Member still wants the information, he can put in a question and it will be made available. He also wants to know whether a locally-domiciled resident who invests in industry will be given permanent residence. If a person is locally-domiciled, it means that he is allowed to stay here and, in time to come, he will qualify for citizenship. Is that what the Member wants to know?

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: No, Sir. I am referring to a person staying in Singapore but who holds a foreign passport. Therefore, he is not domiciled here. He is a national of another country residing in Singapore.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Then he comes under the category of persons who apply for permanent residence with an investment of $1/4 million. If the person so mentioned by the Member for Changi wants permanent residence, he will apply in the normal way as the others. There is no difference between them. If he is thinking of investing or has invested $1/4 million --

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Sir, he has invested millions of dollars in industry, hotels and other projects, and he is trying to apply for permanent residence on the strength that he has already invested in Singapore prior to the introduction of the scheme to give permanent residence to foreigners who invest $125,000.

Column: 970



    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker Sir, I must confess that I am unaware of such cases. It is not because of ignorance. If a man is astute enough to have earned a few million dollars, I think he is astute enough to take advantage of any scheme that we may have so that he can obtain permanent residence.

    Sir, to come to the other Members, I think there are two points in common which they raised. One is with regard to the entry of non-citizen wives and children of Singapore citizens. What they are asking for is a liberalisation of the law which permits non-citizen wives and children of Singapore citizens to come into Singapore on a permanent residence basis. I think it will help a great deal and will save a lot of time if I mention briefly the conditions under which non-citizen wives and children of Singapore citizens are eligible to apply for permanent residence in the Republic. These are laid down in section 10 of the Immigration Ordinance, 1955, and in the consideration of applications various factors are taken into consideration; namely, (a) whether the marriage is lawful; (b) whether the wife and children qualify under paragraphs 4 and 5 of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1966. i.e., whether the wife has not been living separately from the husband for a continuous period of five years after the date of the marriage, and whether the children are under six years of age.

    Here, may I digress a little and take up the points raised by the Member for Delta on a specific case? She probably knows more about Chinese customs than I do. But my understanding is that the Chinese of this generation of about 50 years and over, more often than not, would prefer to take more than one wife! Here again, without going into the case specifically, I have my doubts whether this is a bona fide case of husband and wife because, normally, again I stand to be corrected, according to Chinese custom, usually the husband is much older than the wife. In this instance, the wife appears to be seven years older than the husband. Therefore, I think the application was not approved

Column: 971

because the Immigration officials may have doubts whether that was a bona fide case of love at first sight, or whatever it is.

    The Member for Delta also mentioned that they had not been living together for five years because attempts had been made during that time for the wife to gain entry here. First, the wife was sick and there was the question of permits. If they were so much in love and if the husband really required the presence of his wife here, it would not have taken five years to go through the official procedure. And if he could live - I presume that he lived well.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): Point of clarification, Sir. The Minister should not forget that the cause of the delay was that the wife could not come here unless she is older than the specified age limit.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, this is a different matter, The Member says the woman had not reached the specified age. At first, probably the application was prepared wrongly. As far as I understand, the application was made on the ground that she is the wife of a local resident. If she is the wife of a local citizen, it is not the age that is to be taken into consideration. It is the other factors which I have mentioned.

    I will now come to the third factor to which consideration will be given for admitting non-citizen wives and children of Singapore citizens. It is whether the husband is in a position to support his wife and children. We are not a hard-hearted Government and I believe the Ministers here have got feelings. At the same time, in deciding upon policy, we must not allow ourselves to be swayed by sentiment. The only sentiment we should allow ourselves to be swayed by is, is it for the good of Singapore? If it is for the good of Singapore, then we will carry out the policy. And once a policy has been decided, as my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, has said, we must stand firm.

Column: 972

On the question of entry permits, we do relax the regulations sometimes under exceptional circumstances, because of our feelings, our sentiments, and on humanitarian grounds. We are not that hard-hearted as was made out to appear by the Member for Delta.

    I will now take up the suggestion put up by the Member for Changi that there should be closer liaison between the Registry of Marriages and the Immigration Department. He suggests that Singapore citizens who intend to marry non-citizens should be provided with a questionnaire. I do not know what questions he has in mind.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Questions like how much money the person has and whether he can support the woman.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, as I said, if a man is intent on, marrying a woman out of love, no amount of prevention by any Government official will stop that marriage. But I think we have announced time and time again - and I have just made it clear - the conditions under which we will allow a non-citizen wife to enter Singapore.

    To take up the point again that we have no feelings, as my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, said the other day, it is only those cases which have not been approved that come to Members' notice. Cases that have been approved do not come back to thank them for their assistance. For the information of Members, I would like to give some figures. In 1968, there were a total of 910 applications of Malaysian wives of Singapore citizens. Out of these 910 applications, 742 were approved. In 1969, out of 902 applications. 795 were approved. So you will see that we have not been very hard-hearted in enforcing this regulation, and whenever we can, we will let them through and make life happier for our citizens who have married non-citizen wives.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Hear, hear!

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, as regards applications which were not approved, namely, 168 in 1968 and 107 in 1969,

Column: 973

these were mainly due to the fact that the husbands' income was low and they were not considered to have capacity lo support their wives, much less their children, later on in Singapore. I think that answers the point raised by the Member for Anson.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Point of clarification, Sir. I quite agree with the Minister's reply. But what happens if a citizen brings in a non-citizen wife and the next day he wins a lottery prize of $400,000?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not gamble on the future of Singapore.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: But what about the lottery and the gambling that is now going on in Singapore?

    Mr Lim Kim San: That is gambling. But I hope the Member for Anson will listen closely to me. I said we do not gamble on the future of Singapore. We take no chances with the future of Singapore.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Yes, I agree.

    Mr Lim Kim San: I may not have heard the Member for Toa Payoh correctly. Singapore citizens do not require work permits to take up employment in Singapore. Is that the Member's question?

    Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee: When they were in Malaysia, they had work permits in order to be able to work. When their work permits were withdrawn, they wanted to bring their families to Singapore. The men were allowed to come in, but not their wives and children.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Their applications to bring in their wives and children would be governed by the three factors that I have mentioned. If they are economically viable, there is no reason why their wives and children cannot be allowed in. As I have indicated, about eight out of ten applications have been approved.

Column: 974



    The Member for Telok Blangah asked why non-citizens have to pay $24.60 for a certificate of identity when citizens pay $25 for an international passport which is valid for five years. As a Singapore citizen, you have certain privileges. Surely we should treat our citizens better than non-citizens. And for these certain privileges - privileges over and above those not enjoyed by non-citizens, and I think every country does that - our citizens have got more responsibilities than non-citizens. I think the Member is also mistaken because the fee for a restricted certificate of identity for travelling to West Malaysia is only $5 and not $24.60. The sum of $24.60 is charged for an intemational certificate of identity for travel overseas other than West Malaysia.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: On a point of clarification, Sir. I think the present fee for a certificate of identity for travelling to Malaysia, including the re-entry permit charges, etc, is $24.60.

    Mr Lim Kim San: May I take some time to check the figures again, Sir? Either the typist has made a mistake here or the Member has been misinformed. My information is that in the case of a restricted certificate of identity for direct travel between West Malaysia and Singapore, the fee is $5. However, I am willing to go back and seek further clarification. If there is a different charge for citizens and non-citizens, there is a very good reason for it. As far as possible, I will keep this distinction because it indicates how valuable Singapore citizenship is. A Singapore citizen has more privileges than a non-citizen. This is as it should be.

    May I clarify how a certificate of identity is issued? It is governed by Article 28 of the United Nations Final Act and Convention. It is an International Geneva Agreement. It requires that before we can issue a certificate of identity to a person, he must produce documentary evidence from his country of birth that he is stateless, and if he can produce that evidence, then he will

Column: 975

be issued with a certificate of identity with re-entry facilities upon application. This is to prevent anyone issuing a certificate of identity from infringing on the rights of the country in which the applicant is born. That is why the applicant is covered by an international convention. That is the law and, as the Member for Delta has said, laws are made by man and they can be un-made by man. She said that we must have some human consideration in the application of the law. We have shown human consideration here. That is why in genuine cases where special consideration justifies it, we issue a certificate of identity to a person who is normally not eligible for such travel facilities.

    The Member for Telok Blangah has suggested that we should accept a telephone call as evidence. I think he has a higher regard for the honesty of the average man than we who have worked in the Government for some time have. I will not take the responsibility of directing my officer to accept a telephone call as genuine evidence.

    The Member for Havelock wants to know the rationale for not issuing passports to Singapore citizens abroad who have forgotten or have not renewed their passports in time. There are many reasons, some of which I cannot divulge. It may be that during a person's stay abroad, he may have been involved in activities which constitute a security risk to us when he returns. May I remind Members that the issue of a passport to any applicant is not one of right? It is a privilege.
